description:
Pseudomonas fluorescens SBW25 is a Gram-negative, aerobic, rod-shaped bacterium belonging to the genus Pseudomonas. It is known for its ability to produce a yellow-green fluorescent pigment called pyoverdin, which is a siderophore involved in iron acquisition.

Pseudomonas fluorescens SBW25 is a well-studied model organism in the field of microbial ecology and evolutionary biology. It was isolated from the phyllosphere (the surface of plant leaves) of a sugar beet plant in the United Kingdom.

This strain is known for its diverse metabolic capabilities, which allow it to thrive in a wide range of environmental conditions. It is a ubiquitous soil bacterium and can also be found in aquatic environments, plant surfaces, and animal-associated habitats.

Pseudomonas fluorescens SBW25 has been extensively studied for its plant growth-promoting properties, such as the production of antifungal compounds, the solubilization of phosphates, and the induction of systemic resistance in plants. It has also been investigated for its potential use in bioremediation processes, as it can degrade a variety of organic compounds.

The genome of Pseudomonas fluorescens SBW25 has been sequenced, and it has been used as a model organism to study bacterial adaptation, evolution, and the interactions between bacteria and their environment.
